metadata.title: A Structured Prediction Approach for Label Ranking
metadata.author: Anna Korba, Alexandre Garcia, Florence d'Alché-Buc
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: We propose to solve a label ranking problem as a structured output regression task. In this view, we adopt a least square surrogate loss approach that solves a supervised learning problem in two steps: a regression step in a well-chosen feature space and a pre-image (or decoding) step. We use specific feature maps/embeddings for ranking data, which convert any ranking/permutation into a vector representation. These embeddings are all well-tailored for our approach, either by resulting in consistent estimators, or by solving trivially the pre-image problem which is often the bottleneck in structured prediction. Their extension to the case of incomplete or partial rankings is also discussed. Finally, we provide empirical results on synthetic and real-world datasets showing the relevance of our method.

highlights: Label ranking is a prediction task which aims at mapping input instances to a order over a given set of labels indexed by {1, . . . , K}
In pattern recognition for instance (Geng and Luo, 2014), label ranking can be used to predict the different objects which are the more likely to appear in an image among a predefined set

Our contribution is three folds: (1) we cast the label ranking problem into the structured prediction framework and propose embeddings dedicated to ranking representation, (2) for each embedding we propose a solution to the pre-image problem and study its algorithmic complexity and (3) we provide theoretical and empirical evidence for the relevance of our method

In section 2, definitions and notations of objects considered through the paper are introduced, and section 3 is devoted to the statistical setting of the learning problem. section 4 describes at length the embeddings we propose and section 5 details the theoretical and computational advantages of our approach
We present the results obtained with two regressors : Kernel Ridge regression (Ridge) and k-Nearest Neighbors
The structured prediction approach we propose comes along with theoretical guarantees and efficient algorithms, and its performance has been shown on real-world datasets

In pattern recognition for instance (Geng and Luo, 2014), label ranking can be used to predict the different objects which are the more likely to appear in an image among a predefined set
In sentiment analysis, (Wang et al, 2011) where the prediction of the emotions expressed in a document is cast as a label ranking problem over a set of possible affective expressions

The prediction of preferences of a web user over ad categories (Djuric et al, 2014) can be formalized as a label ranking problem, and the prediction as a ranking guarantees that each user is qualified into several categories, eliminating overexposure
Where the goal is to rank a set of algorithms according to their suitability based on the characteristics of a target dataset and learning problem; Aiguzhinov et al (2010))

In section 2, definitions and notations of objects considered through the paper are introduced, and section 3 is devoted to the statistical setting of the learning problem. section 4 describes at length the embeddings we propose and section 5 details the theoretical and computational advantages of our approach

We will compare our numerical results with the best performances attained by these methods on a set of benchmark datasets of the label ranking problem in section 6.
3 Structured prediction for label ranking
3.1

summary: Label ranking is a prediction task which aims at mapping input instances to a order over a given set of labels indexed by {1, . . . , K}.

Our contribution is three folds: (1) we cast the label ranking problem into the structured prediction framework and propose embeddings dedicated to ranking representation, (2) for each embedding we propose a solution to the pre-image problem and study its algorithmic complexity and (3) we provide theoretical and empirical evidence for the relevance of our method.
We will compare our numerical results with the best performances attained by these methods on a set of benchmark datasets of the label ranking problem in section 6.

We propose to study how to solve this problem and its empirical counterpart for a family of loss functions based on some ranking embedding φ : SK → F that maps the permutations σ ∈ SK into a Hilbert space F :

This loss presents two main advantages: first, there exists popular losses for ranking data that can take this form within a finite dimensional Hilbert Space F, second, this choice benefits from the theoretical results on Surrogate Least Square problems for structured prediction using Calibration Theory of Ciliberto et al (2016) and of works of Brouard et al (2016) on Structured Output Prediction within vector-valued Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Spaces.

These works approach Structured Output Prediction along a common angle by introducing a surrogate problem involving a function g : X → F and a surrogate loss L(g(x), σ) to be minimized instead of Eq 1.

We study three embeddings tailored to represent full rankings/permutations in SK and discuss their properties in terms of link with the ranking distances ∆τ and ∆H , and in terms of algorithmic complexity for the pre-image problem (5) induced.
Motivated by the minimization of the Kendall’s τ distance ∆τ , we study the Kemeny embedding, previously introduced for the ranking aggregation problem): φτ : SK → RK(K−1)/2 σ → − σ(i)))1≤i<j≤K .
The Kemeny embedding can be naturally extended to partial and incomplete rankings since it encodes relative information about the positions of the items.
The Hamming embedding, since it encodes the absolute positions of the items, is tricky to extend to map partial or incomplete rankings where this information is missing.
The fact that the Lehmer embedding performs well for the optimization of the Kendall’s τ distance highlights its practical relevance for label ranking.
This paper introduces a novel framework for label ranking, which is based on the theory of Surrogate Least Square problem for structured prediction.
The framework of prediction with abstention should be of interest
headline: We propose to solve a label ranking problem as a structured output regression task
